 <span class="bdbLangHebrew">‎מָנֶה‎</span> **noun masculine** ==maneh, mina==, a weight (perhaps originally ***a specific part***; Late Hebrew ***id.***; Assyrian <abbr title="transliteration"><u>***manû***</u></abbr> [[BDB#Dl|Dl]]<sup>HWB 417</sup>; Aramaic <img class="bdbSeriacGlyph" src="data:image/gif;base64,">, <span class="bdbLangHebrew">‎מַנְיָא‎</span>); — <span class="bdbLangHebrew">‎׳‎</span><span class="bdbLangHebrew">‎מ‎</span> [[Ezek.45.12|Ezek 45:12]] <span class="bdbLangHebrew">‎מָנִים‎</span> [[1Kgs.10.17|1Kgs 10:17]] + 3 t.; = 50 shekels [[Ezek.45.12|Ezek 45:12]] (on <span class="bdbLangHebrew">‎חֲמִשִּׁים‎</span> for <span class="bdbLangHebrew">‎חֲמִשָּׁה‎</span> see [[BDB#Hi|Hi]] [[BDB#Co|Co]]); of gold [[1Kgs.10.17|1Kgs 10:17]] of silver [[Ezra.2.69|Ezra 2:69]]; [[Neh.7.71|Neh 7:71]]; [[Neh.7.72|Neh 7:72]]. — The weight of the mina was 1/60 of talent; i.e. according to older (Babylonian) standard, 982.2 grammes (= 60 shekels at approximately 16.37 g.) = approximately 2 lbs.; in Ezekiel's time the mina = 50 shekels = 818.6 g. = approximately 1 2/3 lb. (compare <span class="bdbLangHebrew">‎כִּכָּר‎</span>, <span class="bdbLangHebrew">‎שֶׁקֶל‎</span>). See J. [[BDB#Benz|Benz]]<sup>Archaeology 187 ff.</sup> 194 [[BDB#Now|Now]]<sup>Archaeology i. 208 f</sup>.
